title: Mobile Application Development (MSc)
objectives: Welcome to the Mobile Application Development Module. The primary objective of this course will be to provide a further introduction to developing modern Android Applications in Java. The course will comprise of a series of Talks + labs exploring the Android development ecosystem in increasing detail. Our objective is to provide the student with the skills required to construct a relatively complex Android application. A good knowledge of Java and programming is assumed.

los.title: Assignment
los.objectives: A detailed specification of the Mobile Application Development assignment.

topics.title: Module Overview & Background
topics.objectives: Here you'll find a brief talk about myself, my background and what this Module will cover in the different sections.

los.title: 01: Module Overview
los.objectives: Here you'll find a brief talk about myself, my background and what this Module will cover in the different sections.

topics.title: Overview & Tools
topics.objectives: In this section we take a first look at Android, it's User Interface and the major components that make up an Android application. When you're finished this section you should be familiar with the Android ecosystem, be aware of the major Android application components, be able to build a simple Android app and be able to deploy an Android app to an emulator and run/test it

los.title: 00: App Design
los.objectives: Here we discuss app design in general, the frameworks available to the app developer and the different approaches that can be followed in the design and development of a mobile app.

los.title: 01: Android Overview
los.objectives: Here we take a brief look and Android, explore the general context of the android User Experience, it's role in the mobile platform space and the components that make up the the system. We are particularly interested in the version numbers and how version in general is managed.

los.title: 02: Android Anatomy
los.objectives: Here we take a closer look at the Android eco-system and the components that make up this system. We are particularly interested in both the android activity and fragment life-cycles and the android components that we utilise to build an android app.

los.title: HelloWorld
los.objectives: Here we discuss how to install and set up effective tools for Android application development. These include the Android Studio IDE + an emulator. We'll also create a simple Android App (HelloWorld), and be able to manage it within the Android Studio environment.

los.title: Lab-01
los.objectives: This lab introduces our Case Study CoffeeMate with a look at some of the basic features we can implement in an Android App.

topics.title: UI Design, Navigation & App Structure
topics.objectives: Here we discuss app design in general, the frameworks available to the app developer and the different approaches that can be followed in the design and development of a mobile app. We begin with some of the more common widgets and complete the material with some of the more advanced UI artifacts used in the design of android apps, focusing on the android UI guidelines for effective navigation.

los.title: 03: UI Design - Part 1
los.objectives: Here we discuss app design in general, the frameworks available to the app developer and the different approaches that can be followed in the design and development of a mobile app.

los.title: 04: UI Design - Part 2
los.objectives: Here we build on the previous section and look at some of the more advanced UI features used in the design of android apps and focus on filtering and searching.

los.title: Lab-02
los.objectives: In this Lab, CoffeeMate.2.0 we will build on the previous lab and add in some new features and UI Design. On completion of this lab you'll be able to use Bundles, Custom Layouts, Custom Adapters and Fragments.

los.title: Lab-03
los.objectives: In this Lab, CoffeeMate.3.0 we will again build on the previous lab and add in more new features and UI Design. On completion of this lab you'll be able to use multiple Fragments in different Activities, use Spinners (dropdown lists), filter lists and use the Application Object

los.title: 05: UI Navigation
los.objectives: Here we investigate some of the more advanced UI artifacts used in the design of android apps and focus on the android UI guidelines for effective navigation.

los.title: Lab-04
los.objectives: This lab continues our Case Study CoffeeMate but with a major refactoring of the UI (using a Navigation Drawer) and a more detailed look at the use of Fragments in an Android App.

topics.title: Data Persistence in Android
topics.objectives: This first application is already composed of a range of classes related to each other via different types of relationships. We can capture this design graphically in UML, exploring the true nature of the structure of the app. We then move on to a new version of the app though which we will explore the major features of the SDK.

los.objectives: This lab continues our Case Study CoffeeMate and implements persistence (through an SQLite Database) in an Android App.

topics.title: Multithreading & Networking
topics.objectives: In this section we take a brief look at persistence within an Android app (via SQLite) but focus mainly on how the Android OS implements multithreading and deals with running tasks in the background. We also investigate the different approaches available to the developer for making http calls and API requests.

los.objectives: In this section we take a brief look at persistence within an Android app (via SQLite) but focus mainly on how the Android OS implements multithreading and deals with running tasks in the background. We also investigate the different approaches available to the developer for making http calls and API requests.

los.title: 10: Android & Retrofit
los.objectives: Rework the CoffeeMate application to access and update the REST interface exposed by coffeemateweb.herokuapp.com.

los.title: Lab-06-a
los.objectives: This lab continues our Case Study CoffeeMate with the introduction of a VOLLEY API to interact with a Node Web Server.

los.title: Lab-06-b
los.objectives: This lab continues our Case Study CoffeeMate with the introduction of a RETROFIT API to interact with a Node Web Server.

topics.title: Google Services
topics.objectives: Google Services is a layer of services Android apps can use. This includes location services, google sign-in, cloud, contacts, maps etc. Here we focus on just 3 of the services - Google+ Sign-in, Location and Maps.

los.title: Google Services, Sign In, Location & Maps
11: Google Sign-in Integration
los.objectives: Here we discuss the steps necessary to integrate Google Sign-in into an Android app, using our Case Study (CoffeeMate) and the labs to demonstrate.

los.title: 12: Google Location Services
los.objectives: Here we discuss the steps necessary to integrate Google Location Services into an Android app, using our Case Study (CoffeeMate) and the labs to demonstrate.

los.title: 13: Google Maps
los.objectives: Here we discuss the steps necessary to integrate Google Maps into an Android app, using our Case Study (CoffeeMate) and the labs to demonstrate.

los.title: Lab-07
los.objectives: This lab continues our Case Study CoffeeMate and once again, yet another major refactoring of the app, where we introduce some basic security using Google Sign-in.

los.title: Lab-08
los.objectives: This lab is the final lab in the current version and completes our Case Study CoffeeMate with the introduction of Location Awareness and Google Maps in version CoffeeMate.8.0.
